entry.title: Markdown testing
entry.content:
Testing markdown in new theme.

This is intended as a quick reference and showcase. For more complete info, see John Gruberâ€™s original spec and the Github-flavored Markdown info page.

This cheatsheet is specifically Markdown Hereâ€™s version of Github-flavored Markdown. This differs slightly in styling and syntax from what Github uses, so what you see below might vary a little from what you get in a Markdown Here email, but it should be pretty close.

Table of Contents

Headers
Emphasis
Lists
Links
Images
Code and Syntax Highlighting
Blockquotes
Inline HTML
Horizontal Rule
Line Breaks

## Headers

H1

H2

H3

H4

H5
H6

Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ish style:

Alt-H1

Alt-H2

## Emphasis

Emphasis, aka italics, with asterisks or underscores.

Strong emphasis, aka bold, with asterisks or underscores.

Combined emphasis with asterisks and underscores.

## Lists
  1. First ordered list item
  2. Another item
  • Unordered sub-list.

  1. Actual numbers donâ€™t matter, just that itâ€™s a number

  2. Ordered sub-list

  3. And another item.

    Some text that should be aligned with the above item.

  • Unordered list can use asterisks
  • Or minuses
  • Or pluses
## Links

There are two ways to create links.

Iâ€™m an inline-style link

Iâ€™m a reference-style link

You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions

Or leave it empty and use the link text itself

Some text to show that the reference links can follow later.

## Images

Hereâ€™s our logo (hover to see the title text):

Inline-style:

Reference-style:

## Code and Syntax Highlighting

Code blocks are part of the Markdown spec, but syntax highlighting isnâ€™t. However, many renderers â€“ like Githubâ€™s and Markdown Here â€“ support syntax highlighting. Markdown Here supports highlighting for dozens of languages (and not-really-languages, like diffs and HTTP headers); to see the complete list, and how to write the language names, see the highlight.js demo page.

Inline code has back-ticks around it.

Blocks of code are either fenced by lines with three back-ticks ```, or are indented with four spaces. I recommend only using the fenced code blocks â€“ theyâ€™re easier and only they support syntax highlighting.

(Github Wiki pages donâ€™t seem to support syntax highlighting, so the above wonâ€™t be colourful (the strings are not red, for example). Try it out in a Markdown Here email or a Github Markdown README or Github Issue â€“ you can preview a new Issue without submitting it.)

Again, to see what languages are available for highlighting, and how to write those language names, see the highlight.js demo page.

## Blockquotes

Blockquotes are very handy in email to emulate reply text.
This line is part of the same quote.

Quote break.

This is a very long line that will still be quoted properly when it wraps. Oh boy letâ€™s keep writing to make sure this is long enough to actually wrap for everyone. Oh, you can put Markdown into a blockquote.

## Inline HTML

You can also use raw HTML in your Markdown, and itâ€™ll mostly work pretty well. Here are a couple of common examples:

Definition list
Is something people use sometimes.
Markdown in HTML
Does *not* work **very** well. Use HTML tags.
Tables Are Cool
Zebra Stripes Are Pretty
Here Is Another Row

Github-flavored Markdown supports a special table syntax, but Markdown Here does not support it yet. Thereâ€™s an issue for it.

## Horizontal Rule

Three or moreâ€¦

Hyphens

Asterisks

Underscores

## Line Breaks

My basic recommendation for learning how line breaks work is to experiment and discover â€“ hit <Enter> once, then hit it twice, see what happens. Youâ€™ll soon learn to get what you want. â€œMarkdown Toggleâ€ is your friend.

Here are some things to try out:

With only a single newline, this line and
this line will be a single line.

But this one is separated by two newlines and so will be a separate paragraph.

This line has two spaces at the end (hard for you to see, but trust me!).
So this is a separate line in the same paragraph.
